overview: From 2025-10-26 to 2025-11-02, elizaos/elizaos.github.io had 0 new PRs (2 merged), 1 new issues, and 5 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Weekly Summary on profiles displaying incorrect week + date
topIssues.author: Vianvolaeus
topIssues.body: Looks like most Weekly Summaries on the leaderboard at stuck on week dated 13th-19th July 2025, though there are [some exceptions](https://elizaos.github.io/profile/madjin), where the date is different. Either way, appears to be incorrect range / date.

topPRs.title: feat: Implement MVP Badge System for Contributor Achievements
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Overview

Implements a minimal, efficient badge/achievement system with **5 badge types** across **3 tier levels** (beginner/elite/legend). Designed with DRY and YAGNI principles to minimize code overhead (~370 lines vs 2000+ for alternative approaches).

## Badge Types

- **Level Milestones**: Beginner (10), Elite (30), Legend (50)
- **Activity Streaks**: 7, 30, 60 consecutive days
- **PR Master**: 5, 25, 100 merged PRs
- **Bug Hunter**: 3, 15, 50 bug fixes
- **Review Champion**: 10, 50, 200 code reviews

## Implementation Approach

### âœ… Chosen: Ultra-Minimal Strategy (~370 LOC)

**Key Decisions:**
- **On-demand calculation** - No progress storage, reuses existing queries
- **TypeScript constants** - Badge definitions in code (no DB table needed)
- **Component reuse** - Extended `SkillCard` with badge mode prop
- **Highest tier only** - UNIQUE DB constraint prevents duplicates
- **Parallel to tags** - Separate concept but follows similar patterns

**Benefits:**
- âœ… Minimal maintenance surface area
- âœ… Zero storage overhead for progress tracking
- âœ… Maximum reuse of existing infrastructure
- âœ… Fast to implement and validate

### ðŸ”„ Alternative Strategies Considered

**1. Moderate Approach (~600 LOC)**
- Badge definitions stored in database
- Separate evaluator functions per badge type
- Progress calculation helper functions
- Badge detail modal component

*Trade-off:* More extensible but violates YAGNI since badge requirements unlikely to change frequently.

**2. Config-Driven Approach (~800 LOC)**
- Badge requirements in `pipeline.config.ts` like scoring rules
- Generic rule engine evaluates any badge from config
- Admin API to modify requirements without code changes

*Trade-off:* Maximum flexibility but significant complexity increase. Only needed if requirements change often (they won't).

## Technical Details

### Database
- New `user_badges` table with 7 columns
- UNIQUE constraint on `(username, badgeType)` enforces highest tier only
- Foreign key to users with CASCADE delete
- Migration: `drizzle/0013_add_user_badges.sql`

### Core Logic (3 files, 550 lines)
- `src/lib/badges/types.ts` - Badge definitions with emoji icons & colors
- `src/lib/badges/checker.ts` - Eligibility checking (reuses 5 existing query functions)
- `src/lib/badges/award.ts` - Award/upgrade logic with automatic deduplication

### Pipeline Integration
- New `processContributorBadges` step in contributor pipeline
- Runs after tag and score calculation
- Parallel processing for all contributors
- ~20 lines added to existing pipeline

### Frontend
- Extended `SkillCard` component with `mode="badge"` prop
- New "Achievements" section in user profile pages
- Trophy icon and badge count display
- Tooltip shows earned date and description

## Trust & Anti-Gaming

- âœ… Only tracks **whitelisted repositories** (24 repos)
- âœ… Merged PRs require **maintainer approval**
- âœ… Bug labels set by **maintainers**
- âœ… Streak requires **sustained effort** (no backdating possible)
- âœ… All thresholds based on **actual contributor distribution**

## Testing

âœ… TypeScript compilation passes  
âœ… ESLint passes (no new warnings)  
âœ… Database schema validated  
âœ… Pipeline integration tested  
âœ… UI components render correctly

## Usage

After merging:
1. Run migration: `bun run db:migrate`
2. Process contributors: `bun run pipeline process`
3. Build site: `bun run build`
4. Badges appear on user profile pages

## Files Changed

**Created (4 files):**
- `drizzle/0013_add_user_badges.sql`
- `src/lib/badges/types.ts`
- `src/lib/badges/checker.ts`
- `src/lib/badges/award.ts`

**Modified (6 files):**
- `src/lib/data/schema.ts` - Added userBadges table
- `src/lib/pipelines/contributors/index.ts` - Badge processing step
- `src/app/profile/[username]/queries.ts` - Badge fetching query
- `src/app/profile/[username]/page.tsx` - Pass badges to component
- `src/app/profile/[username]/components/UserProfile.tsx` - Achievements section
- `src/components/skill-card.tsx` - Badge display mode

---

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

topPRs.title: feat: Add adaptive rate limiting with low-volume optimization
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary

This PR implements **adaptive rate limiting with low-volume optimization** for GitHub API operations, providing significant performance improvements for high-volume repositories while maintaining zero overhead for typical workloads.

### Key Features

1. **Adaptive Concurrency Manager** - Dynamically adjusts concurrent operations (3-8) based on rate limit health
2. **Enhanced Rate Limit Detection** - Distinguishes primary vs secondary rate limits for better error handling
3. **Low-Volume Optimization** - Batch threshold (default 50 items) prevents overhead on small batches
4. **Production-Tested** - Validated with 14 Optimism repos (283 items/week)

### Performance Impact

**High-volume repos (Optimism - 283 items/week)**:
- Actual results: **8 minutes** (vs projected 20 minutes with static concurrency)
- Performance improvement: **60% faster**

**Low-volume repos (ElizaOS - 63 items/week)**:
- No change: **4-5 minutes** (batch threshold prevents overhead)
- Performance impact: **Zero overhead**

### Code Changes

- **Net change**: +195 lines (407 additions, 212 deletions)
- **Files modified**: 5
  - `src/lib/data/github.ts`: Core adaptive system (+134 net)
  - `src/lib/pipelines/types.ts`: Batch threshold integration (+49 net)
  - `src/lib/pipelines/ingest/index.ts`: Enable adaptive (+3 net)
  - `config/pipeline.config.ts`: Testing config (+10 net)
  - `cli/analyze-pipeline.ts`: Simplified ingestion (-1 net)

### Design Decisions

**Removed YAGNI features** (33% reduction from initial implementation):
- API cost estimation (~80 lines) - Token bucket already prevents rate limit issues
- Graceful shutdown (~26 lines) - Database writes are transactional, re-runs skip processed items
- Unused tracking code (~10 lines) - Dead code cleanup

**Retained core features**:
- AdaptiveConcurrencyManager class (~48 lines) - Proven 60% improvement
- Rate limit type detection (~50 lines) - Better error handling
- Batch threshold logic (~6 lines) - Zero overhead for low volumes
- Pipeline integration (~58 lines) - Seamless opt-in activation

### Why This Matters

This PR is **future-proof architecture**:
- Current ElizaOS workload sees zero overhead (batch threshold optimization)
- As repo activity grows, adaptive concurrency kicks in automatically
- No configuration changes needed - works out of the box
- Opt-in via `adaptiveConcurrency: true` in pipeline config

### Testing

All checks pass:
- âœ… TypeScript compilation (`bunx tsc --noEmit`)
- âœ… ESLint checks (no new warnings)
- âœ… Production validated (14 repos, 283 items/week, 60% faster)

### Related

- Resolves issue #159 (Adaptive Concurrency for High-Volume Repos)
- Builds on PR #157 (Token Bucket Rate Limiting)
- Builds on PR #158 (Enhance Data Ingestion)

---

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

topContributors.summary: standujar: This week, standujar drove significant feature development, most notably implementing a unified messaging API (`eliza#6095`) and adding critical multi-tenancy support with PostgreSQL Row-Level Security in `eliza#6101`, a complex change with over 2700 lines added. They also shipped several important bug fixes for server stability and agent persistence (`eliza#6105`, `eliza#6106`) and enhanced the Solana plugin with wallet improvements (`plugin-solana#21`). Their work shows a primary focus on new feature implementation, complemented by refactoring and bug fixes across the codebase.

wtfsayo: This week, wtfsayo focused on implementing a new Jobs API for one-off agent messaging in the `elizaos/eliza` repository, merging a significant feature PR (#6098) that added over 5,300 lines of code. They also updated dependencies in the `elizaos-plugins/plugin-mcp` repository (#18) and have two additional PRs open to extend the new Jobs API. Their work was primarily concentrated on feature development, bugfixes, and refactoring across code, tests, and documentation.

odilitime: Made substantial progress on new features and refactors across multiple plugins, opening 6 pull requests with a significant volume of changes (+5981/-1855 lines). This work includes major enhancements like adding a Discord slash command interface (elizaos-plugins/plugin-discord#23) and refactoring the transaction system in the Solana plugin (elizaos-plugins/plugin-solana#24). Their efforts were concentrated on feature development and code improvements for the Anthropic, Discord, EVM, and Solana plugins.

0xbbjoker: Focused on expanding plugin capabilities this week, merging three PRs that delivered new features and a bug fix. They notably added text embedding model support in a significant PR for the OpenRouter plugin (plugin-openrouter#17) and implemented a static provider for listing documents in the knowledge plugin (plugin-knowledge#45). Their work, which also included two peer review approvals, was primarily centered on bug fixes and feature development, with a secondary focus on documentation.

ChristopherTrimboli: Focused on expanding command-line interface capabilities by implementing a new login command for elizaos. This significant feature was delivered in a single large pull request (elizaos/eliza#6100), which included over 1000 lines of new code and associated tests. In addition to this primary contribution, they also supported the team by reviewing and approving two other pull requests.

yungalgo: Focused on enhancing project documentation this week, merging two pull requests in `elizaos/docs`. Their most notable contribution was adding a community call-to-action (elizaos/docs#78) to drive user engagement, with work primarily touching documentation and configuration files.
tcm390: Made a targeted contribution to the elizaos/eliza repository this week, merging a pull request (elizaos/eliza#6104) to allow for custom options.

ai16x402: Focused on expanding the plugin registry this week, opening a pull request to add the new 'kolscan' Solana trading plugin (elizaos-plugins/registry#237). This work consisted of an update to a configuration file.
linear: Focused on project planning this week, creating two issues in elizaos/eliza to define a UI update for social links (#6089) and a new unified messaging API (#6096).

Vianvolaeus: This week, Vianvolaeus contributed by identifying a bug in the weekly summary display, opening issue elizaos/elizaos.github.io#168 to report that profiles were showing an incorrect week and date.
